column2: Endless OS Tour
Welcome to Endless OS!
Everything you need to get started with Endless OS is here - come on, dive in!
OK, we'll stop for now. If you ever need to get back you can find this quest in the Clubhouse!
Hey there, {{user_name}}! Welcome to Endless OS! First things first - Whenever you see a box like this, click the ❯ button to move to the next message.
If you want to leave this tour, use the X button in the upper right of this text box.
Also, if this text box gets in your way, you can move it to the bottom of the screen by clicking the little arrow button just above this text.
Let's get going! Is this your first computer, {{user_name}}?
Congratulations!
OK, you already know a thing or two, then. Great!
Since you've used other computers before, do you want me to explain how Endless OS differs from other OSes, or do you just want the basics?
Tell me the differences!
Just the basics, please.
OK, I'll try and give you examples based on other computers you've used. Which kind were they? Pick the answer that has the most familliar logo.
We'll start fresh, then.
Windows (Microsoft)
macOS (Apple)
Alright, I'll try to use examples from Windows to explain Endless OS.
Alright, I'll try to use examples from macOS to explain Endless OS.

Since this is your first computer, we need to talk a little about the hardware, so that you'll understand later if a program or tutorial tells you to "Press Ctrl + Alt + P to open the command palette", or something like that.
I know you've already figured out the basics of your mouse, since you're clicking on things on the screen! There are a few details and terms you should know, though.
The little arrow on the screen is called the cursor - so if any instructions talk about moving the cursor somewhere, that means move your mouse so that the arrow on the screen goes there.
Your mouse usually has two buttons, left and right, and might also have a scroll wheel in the center.

When something tells you to click, press the left mouse button down once. When something tells you to right-click, press the right mouse button. The right button is usually used for opening menus or lists of options.

You can spin the wheel in the center of your mouse up and down to move the screen up and down when there's more than one screen of information in a program. Some mice even let you press the wheel into the mouse and use it as a third button, known as the middle mouse button. It's rarely used, and your mouse might not have one.
Laptops usually have a touchpad mouse also just called a touchpad. It might or might not have buttons.

If you don't have buttons foryour touchpad, clicking might mean tapping on the touchpad, pressing down on it, or touching a certain area. When something tells you to right-click, you might have to press down with two fingers at once on the touchpad, or press the side of the touchpad. There are a few different ways it could work, so be sure to read your computer's manual.
Some touchpads support swiping with two fingers to scroll windows up and down. Try yours out and see!
Let's move on to the keyboard. You already know how to type all the normal keys, but in the future, you might need to type Ctrl + S, or Ctrl + (some other key).

When something asks you to type Ctrl + S, that means press and hold Ctrl (pronounced as "Control"), then press S, then release both keys. You can hold Ctrl as long as you need to, but if you hold the other key for very long, it will repeat the command.

There are some other keys like Ctrl: There's Alt, and the key between Ctrl and Alt, which is usually called Win or "the Windows Key". On most keyboards it looks like the Windows logo - A square made of 4 squares.
You can use Win to switch between apps, but I'll cover that more when we talk about apps.

Normally, the F Keys (F1-F12) on the top of your keyboard let you do laptop-specific tasks like turning your network connection on and off, adjusting screen brightness, volume, and more. Check the little pictures on them for a better idea of what they do.

Sometimes, though, you might need to use your Fn or Function key, in combination with those F Keys (F1-F12) to do the special action. Check your computer's manual for more information, every computer is different.

Your keyboard might also have a square pad on the far right with a lot of numbers on it - this is usually called the numpad or number pad. These keys will type numbers if Num Lock is on (look for a little light at the top of the keyboard), and will act as arrow keys or other keys if it's off.
Now that you've got a handle on the hardware, let's move on.
We'll begin our tour of Endless OS with what you're looking at now - This is called the Desktop, and it's made up of a few different parts.
The first part is the icon grid. This is where all your Apps show up when you install them - it works a lot like your phone.
This isn't like the desktop on a Mac - You can't put files here, it's more like an extended Dock, or the Launchpad.
This isn't like the Windows Desktop - You can't put files here, only Apps.
The next part is the Search Bar. It searches lots of different info - Your computer, the web, the App Center...
On macOS, you might have used Spotlight to search your files - In Endless OS, you use the Search Bar.
Like the Start Menu in Windows, you can use the Search Bar to find files and programs on your computer.
The final part of the Desktop is the Panel. This is where you'll find system information like the clock, calendar, audio volume, and more. We'll go into more detail about the Panel later.
Like in Windows, this is where you can find your open Apps and system information.
This works mostly like the top bar in macOS, combined with the Dock's ability to see what programs are running.
Now that you know the basics of the Desktop, let's talk about Apps!
Apps are how you run programs on Endless OS, and you install them through the App Center.
Let's open the App Center right now.
You can search for Apps by name or keyword, using the magnifying glass icon in the upper left of the App Center.
The App Center works like the macOS Applications folder - you can use it to see what you have installed.
The App Center works like the Windows Start Menu and the Add/Remove Programs tool - you can use it to search for Apps to install, see what you have installed, and also remove Apps you don't want.
Because you're connected to the internet right now, we could do a quick walkthrough of installing an app. Does that sounds good?
Sure!
Not now, thanks.
Great! OK, Click the magnifying glass in the upper left - the Search button.
Type Frozen Bubble into the search box - you should only get one result.
Click on Frozen Bubble, then click Download, and wait for the progress bar to fill.
There we go! Frozen Bubble is now installed - you could use Launch to start it from the App Center, or run it from the Desktop.
You can play a few rounds now if you want, just press ❯ when you're ready to move on.
No problem, you can always open the App Center later and try on your own.
You can't install any new apps if you're not connected to the internet, but you can still use the App Center to check what's already installed for you to use.
Now, let's run an App - Find LibreOffice Writer on the Desktop, and click on it to launch it.
Type some text - whatever you like, it's not important for this demo.
Remember, if you need to move this text box, you can use click the little arrow right above the text to move it to the bottom of the screen.
Now, move your cursor into the upper-left part of the screen and click on the File menu. Then, move your cursor down the menu to Save, and click that.

A new window will pop up. Type whatever you like in the Name space at the top, then click the blue Save button, or press Enter on your keyboard. Don't worry about where you saved your file, yet - we'll get to that soon.
Now, let's close LibreOffice Writer by clicking the X in the upper right-hand corner of the LibreOffice Writer window.
Closing a program works the same way in Endless OS and Windows - closing the window closes the program.
On a Mac, if you close a window, the program stays running. Here, on Endless OS, if you close the window, it closes the entire program.
Great job! You successfully used an App!
Now, let's learn about files - open the Files App on the Desktop.
Here's where all your files will live! You've already got pre-made folders for Documents, Music, Pictures, Videos, and more.
This is where the Recycle Bin is - It's called the Trash. It works the same way - you can recover files you've deleted, or empty it out.
If you were wondering where the Trash is, it's here, in Files. It works the same way - you can recover files you've deleted, or empty it out.

You might remember that when we saved our file in LibreOffice Writer, it went to a folder called Documents. You can go into Documents by finding it in the main part of the window and double-clicking it, or by looking on the left side of the window, and clicking on it in the sidebar.
Now that we're inside Documents - there's your file!
Double-click on the file to open it in LibreOffice again.
What if you wanted to save this file on a USB stick, or in a specfic place?
Move your cursor into the upper-left part of the screen and click on the File menu. Then, move your cursor down the menu to Save As..., and click that.
This looks a lot like the Save menu you just saw, but now it should look more familliar... It's very close to the Files window that you just used!
You can move to different places on the computer's hard drive using the left sidebar - if you had another USB stick plugged in, for example, that's where it would show up.
OK, you can click Cancel, and close LibreOffice again, using the X in the upper-right.
There's another way you can find files, too. I'll take us back to the Desktop.
Let's pretend you saved a file but didn't remember anything other than part of the name you used. This is where the Search Bar comes in handy. Type your file name in the Search Bar.

Hopefully, you'll see just one entry in the results - that's your file! You might see more than one, but you can usually use the location below the name to figure out if it's the one you're looking for.
You can search more than just files with the Search Bar, too. It can search the Encyclopedia App, and if you're connected to the internet, it can do a web search for you as well.
Since you're connected to the internet, let's try that out. Type breadfruit into the Search Bar, then click Search Google for "breadfruit".
Seems like it's a real thing, cool!
What if you have a couple different Apps open at the same time and want to switch between them? That can get a little confusing, but EOS has some great features to help.
First, you can look at the left side of the panel. The Endless button on the far left will immediately hide everything and take you to the Desktop.

The keyboard can also help you get to the Desktop quickly. Press the Win key to show the desktop, and press it again to return to what you were doing. (Remember, the Win key has 4 squares on it, and it's near Ctrl!)
You can use the panel to switch between apps - The Apps that are open will show upon the left side of the panel, with little dots underneath their icons. You can click the icon to switch to an app.
You can also use the keyboard to switch between Apps. Hold Win and tap Tab repeatedly to cycle through all the apps you have open - Alt + Tab does the same thing.
Wow, I know this is all a lot! If you want to keep going, I have a few more things I can tell you about - but I understand if you're feeling a little overwhelmed.
I'm up for a little more!
I'm OK for now.
What's Hack?
How do I...
<Placeholder for howtos>
OK! You might have seen the Hack icon on the Desktop... Don't worry, your computer hasn't been hacked!

Hack is a toolkit where we guide you through learning a bunch of fun things - programming, 2d art, 3d modeling, music creation, web design, and more! Some of Hack requires an active internet connection, but not all of it - each activity is marked by what it needs. Give it a shot!
Don't worry, your computer hasn't been hacked!
OK, let's keep going!
Now, even though Endless OS is set up to work great by default, it can help to know just a little about its inner workings. Let's talk some more about the Panel, and the Settings window.
Look in the bottom right corner of your screen - Do you see the icons to the left of the date and time? These icons are shortcuts for important information about your computer.
Also, if this text box is still in the bottom-right of the screen, you probably want to move it again - Just use the little arrow right on top of the first sentence, like last time!
The icon on the left, the fan-shaped one, shows the strength of your connection to a Wi-Fi network - it's like the "bars" on your phone.

The left-most icon might look like a fan with a little X on it, or an airplane - either way, it means you're not connected to a Wi-Fi network.
(The airplane means "airplane mode" - all wireless connections turned off.)
The icon that looks like a little speaker gives you an idea of how loud your volume is. If you see a little X on it, that means your speakers or headphones are muted!
You'll also see a little icon that looks like a battery, and I think you can guess what that one means.
You can click on any of these icons to get more detailed information about them.
On the far right, in the corner, is a circle. It might have letters in it, it might be a picture, depending on what you did when you were setting up your user account in Endless OS.
Click that circle, and a menu will pop up. Then. click the entry in the menu named Settings.

The Settings window is how you control all the details of how Endless OS works. On the left side of the Settings window is a scrolling list of all the different categories of things you can change - But most of the time, you'll only need a couple.
You should see some of the more common categories without needing to scroll - Wi-Fi, Background, and Power.

Wi-Fi controls your network connection. You might use this if you're trying to connect to a specific network, turning Wi-Fi off to save battery, or trying to limit your data use because you're connected to network that charges you for data.
Background lets you set your desktop image to whatever you want. You can choose from a bunch of included images, or find your own.
Power lets you change when and why your computer goes to sleep.
Because you have a laptop, you can have your power settings change depending on whether your computer is plugged in or not. Very handy!
Take a look at more categories in Settings if you want, but you shouldn't have to change anything. Endless OS is set up to work correctly, right out of the box.
There's one last category you need to know about - Automatic Updates.
Here the Endless OS Foundation, we're always working to improve Endless OS. We regularly release updates for free to all of our users - all you need is an internet connection to download them.
Applications you install with the App Center are updated for free, as well.
Normally, Automatic Updates are turned on. That means that if you're connected to the internet, the updates will download automatically, without you doing anything.

If you're worried about how much data the updates use, this section has some options you can change - You can schedule when to install updates, change how they download, and change your network connection settings to help save data if you need to.
Congratulations! I know that was a lot, thanks for staying all the way to the end!
You now should know how to use Endless OS for most basic tasks!
Explore all the apps that are already installed, and check out what you can do with them. There's a ton to do!
I hope you have fun with Endless OS - See you around!
